loans.name: Moreen's Group

texts.en:
Moreen's Group is comprised of two hard-working women. Moreen is 17 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past four years, Moreen has been working hard to manage her food stall, where she sells bananas. 

To help expand her business, Moreen requested a loan from BRAC Uganda for 500,000 Ugandan Shillings, which she will use to purchase more bananas. This loan will help Moreen generate greater profits and pay for her siblings' school fees. Moreen hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Moreen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more bananas

loans.name: Ernest

texts.ru:
Эрнест — из Берегово. Ему 35 лет. Он 10 лет занимается бизнесом — торгует строительными материалами: цементом, трубами, проводами, строительными инструментами.  Он владеет двумя торговыми точками в разных селах: одну из них арендует, вторая — уже в его собственности. Когда открыл первый магазин было сложно, потому что ушло какое-то время на раскрутку магазинчика. 
Эрнесту нужны 40 000 гривен для того, чтобы приобрести помещение для второго магазина. Эрнест очень целеустремленный, любит добиваться поставленных целей. Два года назад он развелся с женой.  Но хотя и они и состоят в разводе, Эрнест очень переживает о 10-летней дочери, которая живет с матерью, и теперь стремится как можно больше помогать им. Мечтает вывести бизнес на такой уровень, чтобы обеспечить себя и дочь всем необходимым в будущем.
texts.en:
Ernest is from Beregovo. He is 35 years old. He has been involved in this business for ten years — he trades construction materials: cement, pipes, wires, and building instruments. He runs two trade spots in different villages: one of these he rents, and the second he owns. When he opened the first store, it was challenging because it took some time to promote the shop.

Ernest needs 40,000 hryvnia in order to acquire a facility for the second store. Ernest is very ambitious and loves to achieve his goals. Two years ago, he got divorced from his wife. But even though they are divorced, Ernest is very worried about his 10-year-old daughter, who lives with her mother, and now he strives as he is able to help them. He dreams of growing the business to such a level that he can support himself and his daughter with all the necessities in the future.

loans.use: to buy a facility for his second construction supplies store.

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en:
Zeinab is 49 and unmarried. She lives with a parent and her brother, who is the main source of income for the family.

Zeinab works from home making traditional Lebanese food. She has many customers, but her income from this is minimal.

Today Zeinab is applying for an 810,000 LBP loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to buy additional ingredients so she can increase her production. She wants to develop her business to the point where she can finally earn a good income.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients with which to make her foods.

loans.name: Clara Aurora

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Honduras 2000 se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo, este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas que bañan las costas de este bello lugar,  aquí la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.
En este lugar vive la señora Clara, tiene  55 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene cuatro hijos mayores de edad, tres de ellos aún viven en su casa. Su esposo se dedica a la pesca.
Doña Clara es una muy buena esposa que trabaja el bien de su familia, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa por catalogo y útiles escolares, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes cuando necesitan de alguna prenda, tiene unas vitrinas para exhibir sus prendas y los útiles que vende, les deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Ella lleva cinco años con su negocio el cual le ha dado muy buenos beneficios y con los que ayuda a su marido a salir adelante.
Este crédito es para comprar ropa y útiles escolares. Esta desde el inicio en el  Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque con los créditos financia su negocio. Sus sueños son seguir adelante en su vida y su negocio.
texts.en:
The communal bank Honduras 2000 meets biweekly in the canton of Jaramijo, which is known for its beautiful beaches along the coast. Most of its residents are hardworking fishermen. This is where Clara lives. She is 55 years old, married, and has four adult children from her marriage, three of whom still live at home. Her husband is a fisherman.

Clara is a very good wife and works hard for her family. She sells clothing by catalog and also school supplies. She makes her sales door to door and also at home, having her customers come over when they need an item of clothing. She has some display cases to show the items and supplies she sells. Her customers make their purchases on credit and she collects their payments every two weeks. She has been in business for five years, and her work has yielded very good profits which she uses to help her husband provide for their family.

She is going to use this loan to buy clothing and school supplies. She has been a part of her communal bank since its inception and she enjoys it because the loans allow her to finance her business. Her goal is to keep her business going and continue moving forward in life.

loans.use: to buy clothing and school supplies.

loans.name: Shakira

texts.en:
Shakira is a hardworking woman. She is 17 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past year, Shakira has been working hard to manage her clothing business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Shakira has requested a loan of 350,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more bed sheets, helping Shakira to generate greater profits and pay her rent. Shakira hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house. 

Shakira is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more bed sheets

loans.name: Anatolyi

texts.ru:
Анатолию — 50 лет. Он женат, дети уже взрослые. Анатолий проживает в с.Малая Кардашинка. Он 21 год занимается тепличным хозяйством. На 30 сотках земли, которой он владеет, Анатолий выращивает ранние и поздние овощи: помидоры, огурцы, пекинскую капусту. 
Сумма в 40 000 гривен понадобилась Анатолию для того, чтобы построить две новые теплицы, так как прежние совсем износились и стали непригодны для ведения хозяйства и выращивания урожаев ранних овощей.
texts.en:
Anatolyi is 50 years old. He is married and his children are already grown. Anatolyi resides in the village Malaya Kardashinka. For 21 years, he has been engaged in greenhouses. On 30 acres of land which he owns, Anatolyi grows early and late vegetables: tomatoes, cucumbers, and Chinese cabbage.

Anatolyi needed a sum of 40,000 hryvnia in order to build two new greenhouses, since the former ones are completely worn out and became unfit for farming and growing crops of early vegetables.

loans.use: to construct two new greenhouses.

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en:
Winfred is 43 years old, married and together with her spouse they have been blessed with five children. She is a farmer and grows cash crops to sell. She has been in this business for the past five years.

She plans to use this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for planting on her farm. She will also buy an irrigation system. She will use the anticipated profits to open a grocery shop.

This is her second loan term from VisionFund Kenya and she paid back her previous loan well. Her future hopes are to grow her business and be successful.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer and an irrigation system.

loans.name: Blanca Nieve

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Honduras 2000 se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo, este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas que bañan las costas de este bello lugar,  aquí la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.
En este lugar vive la señora Blanca, tiene 53 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene 5 hijos, 4 mayores de edad y una de 16 años, todos sus hijos  aún viven en su casa y estudian los mayores en universidad y la menor en colegio. Su esposo se dedica a la pesca.
Doña Blanca se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, cosas de bazar y útiles escolares, ella tiene un local en su casa en el cual también confecciona ropa de todo tipo pues también es modista. Trabaja todos los  días, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Ella lleva 8 años con su negocio y le va muy bien, gracias a sus ganancias y a los créditos ella ha podido ir construyendo de a poco su casa.
Este crédito es para comprar ropa, materiales de costura y artículos de bazar. Esta desde el inicio en el  Grupo De Crédito le gusta porque gracias a uno de los créditos empezó su negocio. Sus sueños son que sus hijos sean buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
The communal bank Honduras 2000 meets biweekly in the canton of Jaramijo, which is known for the beautiful beaches along its coast. Most residents here are fishermen who work very hard. This is where Blanca lives. She is 53 years old, married, and has five children from her marriage. Four of them are adults and the youngest is sixteen. They all still live at home and go to school: the older ones attend university and the youngest is in high school.

Blanca works selling all sorts of clothing, school supplies, and other items. She has a space set up at home where she also makes all types of clothing items, since she is also a seamstress. She works every day and allows her customers to buy on credit, so she collects their payments every two weeks . She has been in business for eight years and things are going very well for her. The profit from her business and the loans she receives have allowed her to build her house little by little.

She will use this loan to buy sewing supplies and other items. She has been a part of her communal bank since its inception and enjoys it because one of the loans allowed her to start her business. Her dream is for her children to earn a college degree and work in their field.

loans.use: to buy clothing, sewing supplies, and other items.

loans.name: Maryory Liliana Mercedes

texts.es:
Maryory es una joven emprendedora y muy responsable, trabaja como Asistente en una empresa agrícola de su ciudad natal, Tinguiña. Actualmente está estudiando la carrera de Administración porque quiere tener una profesión para orgullo de sus padres y para que tenga mayores oportunidades laborales. Su mayor motivación es su familia, por ellos siempre lucha para poder brindarles lo mejor.
Maryory está agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva porque con el apoyo que le han brindado podrá hacer mejoras en su casa como pintarrajear las paredes y comprarse un juego de dormitorio, así sentirá mayor comodidad porque estará mejorando su calidad de vida. Con esto seguirá luchando para mejorar el futuro de su familia
texts.en:
Maryory is an enterprising and very responsible young woman. She works as an assistant for a farming company in her home town, Tinguiña. She is currently studying Administration because she wants to earn a degree and make her parents proud. This will help her have more job opportunities. Her greatest motivation is her family. She always strives to give them all the best.

Maryory is grateful to Kiva lenders because their help will allow her to make home improvements like painting the walls and buying a bedroom set. This way she will live more comfortably and improve her quality of life. She plans to keep fighting for a better future for her family.

loans.use: to paint the walls in her home and buy a bed.

loans.name: Zam

texts.en:
Zam is a hardworking woman. She is 16 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past three years, Zam has been working hard to manage her clothing business, which sells clothes.

To help expand her business, Zam has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more secondhand clothes, and will help Zam to generate greater profits and pay house rent for the family. Zam hopes that in the future she will be able to buy land.

Zam is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: buy more secondhand clothes.

loans.name: Vicenta Margarita

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Honduras 2000 se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo, este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas que bañan las costas de este bello lugar,  aquí la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.
En este lugar vive la señora Vicenta, tiene  67  años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene ocho hijos mayores de edad e independientes. Su esposo ya no trabaja por la edad.
Doña Vicenta tiene un bus de transporte de Jaramijo a  Manta, el cual es conducido por uno de sus hijos a quien le paga un sueldo semanal por su trabajo, además en su casa ella tiene un deposito  de venta de agua en  bidones, ella y su esposo vende en su casa y también entregan a domicilio para lo cual también tiene una persona que es la encargada de realizar esta labor y a quien también le paga un sueldo mensual. Lleva 8 años con este negocio de venta de  agua y muchos años más con el bus de transporte.
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar bidones de agua y ciertos repuestos para el bus. Está en este Grupo De Crédito desde hace más de 12 años. Sus sueños son seguir mejorando su vida y su negocio.
texts.en:
The Honduras 2000 communal bank meets every 15 days in Jaramijo canton. This place is known for its lovely beaches, which bathe the shores of this beautiful place. Here, the majority of residents are very hardworking and earn their livings in fishing.

In this place lives Señora Vicenta. She is 67 years old and married. From this relationship, she has eight independent adult children. Her husband doesn't work because of his age. 

Vicenta has a bus that provides transportation from Jaramijo to Manta. It is driven by one of her sons, to whom she pays a weekly salary for his work. In addition, she has a home business selling large jugs of water. She and her husband sell from their house and they also deliver to residences; she has a person in charge of doing that work to whom she also pays a monthly salary. She has had this water sales business for eight years and the bus for many more years.

She is going to use this loan to buy jugs of water and certain spare parts for the bus. She has been in the communal bank for more than twelve years. Her dream is to continue improving her life and her business.

loans.use: to buy large jugs of water and certain spare parts for the bus

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for hospital expenses, because his wife is having a baby.

loans.name: Norma Ameira

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Honduras 2000 se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo, este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas que bañan las costas de este bello lugar,  aquí la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.
En este lugar vive la señora Norma, tiene  68 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene siete hijos mayores e independientes. Su esposo trabaja con ella. 
Doña Norma y su marido tienen una tienda de víveres en su casa, venden todo tipo de productos de primera necesidad, allí sus clientes encuentran granos, carnes, lácteos,  detergentes, legumbres, helados y muchos otros productos para satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes que a diario visitan su local para surtirse de sus productos, trabajan todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, tienen más de 10 años en su negocio con el cual salen adelante.
Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir más su tienda, va a comprar víveres para satisfacer a sus clientes. Es socia fundadora del  Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque con uno de los créditos empezó su negocio. Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y que su tienda crezca cada día más.
texts.en:
The Honduras 2000 communal bank meets every 15 days in the Jaramijo canton.  This place is known for its beautiful beaches that bathe the coasts of this lovely place.  Most of the inhabitants here are very hard-working and devote themselves to work having to do with the sea.

Norma, age 68, lives in this place.  She is married, and they have seven adult children who are independent.  Her husband works with her.  Norma and her husband have a store at their house where they sell all types of basic needs products.  At the store their customers can find basic grains, meat, dairy products, detergent, vegetables, ice cream, and many other products to meet their needs.  Their customers go to the store daily to stock up on their products.  

They work every day from 6:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m.  Sometimes they work later.  They have had their business for over ten years, and with the business they get ahead.

She will use this loan to stock her store more.  She will buy provisions to satisfy their customers.  

She is a founding member of the communal bank.  She likes it because she started her business with one of the loans.  Her goals are to get ahead in her business and for her store to grow more every day.

loans.use: to buy stock for her store.

loans.name: Olivia's Group

texts.en:
Olivia's Group is comprised of  hard-working women. Olivia is 16 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri, in the Iganga region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past two years, Olivia has been working hard to manage her fish-vending business, in which she sells fish. 

To help expand her business, Olivia has requested a loan of UGX 150,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fish and will help Olivia to generate greater profits and pay house rent. Olivia hopes that, in the future, she will be able to open up a restaurant. 

Olivia is a member of BRAC Uganda's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Riiyeli

texts.en:
Riiyeli is a hardworking woman. She is 17 years old and lives in the town of Busia in the Iganga region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past two years, Riiyeli has been working hard to manage her fish vending business, which sells fish. 

To help expand her business, Riiyeli has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fish and will help Riiyeli to generate greater profits and increase her quantity. Riiyeli hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a restaurant. 

Riiyeli is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fish

loans.name: Nada

texts.en:
Nada is a 36-year-old Lebanese married woman living with her husband, who is an aluminum worker, and four children attending school. 

In 2010, after facing such terrible circumstances, she decided to start working on her own in producing homemade food, which she sells to multiple customers. She states that her revenue is not as much as satisfactory, but it helps the family financially in one way or another. 

Today, with her loan requested from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l., she will purchase necessities to continue producing a good variety of provisions. 

In the future, Nada plans to borrow more Kiva loans with the aim of enhancing her business more and more.

loans.use: to purchase necessities for her homemade food production business.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a hardworking woman. Janet is 17 years old and lives in the town of Busia in the Iganga region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past 3 years, Janet has been working hard to manage her candle making business, which makes candles. 

To help expand her business, Janet has requested a loan of 350,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy a machine and materials, which will help Janet to generate greater profits and rent a business room. Janet hopes that in the future she will be able to become self employed. 

Janet is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy a machine and materials

loans.name: Nino

texts.en:
Nino is a 33-year-old married woman from Telavi district. She lives with her husband and parents-in-law, who get monthly assistance from the local government. Nino's husband is a private artisan and generates 300 GEL monthly. This income however isn't enough for a family of four and they need financial support for reaching normal living condition. 

Nino decided to start her own business and give help for her husband for leading financial difficulties. She requested a loan to MFO Credo and was approved within the joint initiative between Kiva. The loan of 1,500 USD will help her to purchase stock of home products at wholesale prices and then sell it in her community for increased prices. 

Nino will be grateful for giving her a chance to generate her own income and make financial stability for her family. She awaits your support and kindness.

loans.use: To start trading with home products and generate her own income

loans.name: Marcia Del Carmen

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Honduras 2000 se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo, este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas que bañan las costas de este bello lugar,  aquí la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.
En este lugar vive la señora Marcia, tiene 33 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre y de esta relación tiene dos hijos de 16 y 11 años que estudian en colegio y escuela. Su esposo trabaja en una fábrica local y ayuda en el negocio familiar.
Doña Marcia es una mujer que le gusta salir adelante y con su esfuerzo ayudarle a su marido con los gastos que genera el hogar, ellos tienen una tienda de víveres y panadería en un local que arriendan en la ciudad, allí vende todo tipo de productos de primera necesidad  como granos, legumbres, plátano y ciertas bebidas, ella y su marido en la noche elaboran el pan para que en la mañana este todo listo para la venta, en su labor le ayudan sus hijos, lleva más de 14 años con su negocio el cual le da lo necesario para salir adelante.
Este crédito es para comprar víveres para surtir su tienda y productos para elaborar el pan. Lleva 3 años en el grupo de crédito y le gusta porque los créditos le ayudan en  su negocio. Sus sueños son tener un local propio para su negocio.
texts.en:
The communal bank Honduras 2000 meets biweekly in the canton of Jaramijo, which is known for the beautiful beaches along its coast. Most residents here are fishermen who work very hard. This is where Marcia lives. She is 33 years old and is in a common law marriage. She has two children from this relationship, who are ages sixteen and eleven. Her husband works at a local factory and helps run the family business.

Marcia likes getting ahead and strives to help her husband with their household expenses. They run a grocery store and bakery in town, for which they are paying rent. Here she sells all sorts of basic products like grains, legumes, plantains, and certain drinks. Her and her husband bake bread at night so that everything is ready for sale in the morning. Her children also help out. She has been in business for over fourteen years and the store gives her everything she needs in order to get ahead. 

She will use this loan to stock up on groceries for her store and buy ingredients to bake bread. She has been a part of her communal bank for three years and enjoys it because the loans help her with her business. Her dream is to own a space for her business.

loans.use: to buy groceries and baking ingredients.

loans.name: Falelima

texts.en:
Falelima is a 39-year-old married woman with five children. She makes and sells ice cakes in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. 

Falelima needs a loan to buy cordials, sugar, Chinese candy, a large cooler, and foam cups. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. 

Falelima has been a member of SPBD since 2012.

loans.use: to buy cordials, sugar, Chinese candy, a large cooler, and foam cups.

loans.name: Tautau

texts.en: Tautau is 23 years old and unmarried with four children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for one year. Tautau needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a tiller, a spade, a new wheelbarrow, crops, and boots. She has been a member of SPBD since 2014. Tautau will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a tiller, a spade, a new wheelbarrow, crops and boots

loans.name: Charito Magaly

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Honduras 2000 se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo, este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas que bañan las costas de este bello lugar,  aquí la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.
En este lugar vive la señora Charito, tiene 40 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene siete hijos, tres mayores y cuatro de  15, 14, 7 y 6 años, uno de los mayores estudia en universidad y dos en colegio y los menores en escuela. Su esposo es maestro albañil. 
Doña Charito es una ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos y con esto  ayudarle a su esposo en los gastos del hogar se dedica a la cría de pollos, ella tiene en su casa una pequeña granja donde por temporada mete hasta 100 pollos, los mismos que luego de criarlos por un tiempo estimado los vende a amigos y conocidos de la localidad, ella también todas las tardes vende deliciosas empanadas que ella mismo prepara, para lo cual instala un pequeño puesto en las afueras de una tienda que tiene su hermana, con esto ella se gana algo que lo invierte en los estudios de sus hijos.
Este crédito es para comprar alimentos y medicinas para los pollos y víveres para preparar los alimentos. Lleva más de 3 años en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por la ayuda que le dan los créditos. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The Loan Group Honduras 2000 meet every other week in the region of Jaramijo. This place is known for the beautiful beaches that wash the coasts of this lovely place.

Most people here are very hard-working and they perform tasks related to the sea.
 
Charito lives in this place. She is 40 years old, married, and she has 7 children. Three of them are adults, and four are 15,14, 7, and 6 years old respectively. One of the oldest attends college, two are in High school, and the minors go to elementary school.

Her husband is a master builder. Dona Charito is a housewife who raises chickens to obtain her own income, and to be able to help her husband with the house expenses. She has a small farm where she puts up to 100 chickens sometimes. She later sells them to friends and acquaintances around town.

Furthermore, every afternoon, she sells delicious handmade empanadas (turnovers). She has a little stand outside her sister's store. She uses the money she makes to invest it in her children's education.

She'll use this loan to buy food and medicines for the chickens, and supplies to make food.

She's been part of this loan group for over 3 years, and she likes it because the loans help her. Her dreams are to offer her kids the best.

loans.use: to buy food, medicines, and supplies for the chickens.

loans.name: Apaula

texts.en:
Apaula is 36 years old, married, and has nine children. She owns and operates a small store, selling a variety of items, which she has been doing for three years. 

Apaula requested a loan from SPBD, which she will use to buy a new chest freezer, a new display fridge, snacks, soft drinks, frozen goods, and a new scale. She hopes to use her profits to pay for the renovation of her house and her children's education. She became a member of SPBD in 2011 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to purchase a new chest freezer, a new display fridge, snacks, soft drinks, frozen goods, and a new scale

loans.name: María Estrella

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Honduras 2000 se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo, este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas que bañan las costas de este bello lugar,  aquí la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.
En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene  50 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene seis hijos mayores de edad, dos de ellos aun viven con ella y estudian en universidad y otro en colegio a distancia. Su esposo se dedica a la pesca.
Doña 	María es una mujer muy luchadora que le gusta a base de trabajo salir adelante, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes. Trabaja cuatro  días a la semana, ella aprovecha cuando llegan los pescadores para  realizar sus ventas, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Lleva 14 años con su negocio el cual comenzó con el primer crédito que recibió del grupo.
Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisas, camisetas, blusas, interiores, entre otras prendas. Esta desde el inicio en el Grupo De crédito le gusta porque gracias a uno de los créditos empezó su negocio. Sus sueños son tener un local comercial
texts.en:
The Honduras 2000 communal bank meets every 15 days in Jaramijo canton. This place is known for its lovely beaches, which bathe the shores of this beautiful place. Here, the majority of residents are very hardworking and earn their livings in fishing.

In this place lives Señora María. She is 50 years old and married. From this relationship, she has six adult children. Two of them still live with her and study in the university; another is in a distance learning program. Her husband works in fishing.

María is a very determined woman who likes to provide for herself by working. She earns her living selling all kinds of clothing. Her sales method is door-to-door, and she also sells from her house and her customers come to her. She works four days a week. She takes advantage of the arrival of the fishermen to make her sales. She sells to her customers on credit and collects every 15 days. She has had this business for 14 years; she started it with the first loan that this group received.

This loan is to buy pants, shirts, t-shirts, blouses, underwear, and other garments. She has been in the group from the beginning, and she likes it because she started her business thanks to one of the loans. Her dream is to have her own shop.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts, t-shirts, blouses, underwear, and other garments.

loans.name: Mujeres Negociantes Nahuala Group

texts.en:
Nahuala is a municipality located on the PanAmerican Highway in the Western Highlands of Guatemala. It is a vibrant and impoverished town. Nearly the entire population of the municipality is made up of ethnic K'iche' Maya who speak the K'iche' language. The population of the township is estimated to be between 50,000-85,000 individuals with about 10% living in the busy established town center and the remainder living in the outskirts. 

Pascuala is a 31-year-old widow who is a member of the Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Mujeres Negociantes Nahuala” meaning “Businesswomen of Nahuala”.  She has the responsibility to care for three young children who range in age from a year to six years old. Pascuala shares , “I have to fend for my children and take care of all of their needs.” Three years ago, she opened a small shoe store where she sells footwear for women, men and children. The business is going well but Pascuala wants to attract  clients and increase revenue. She is requesting a new loan from Friendship Bridge to purchase more inventory. Pascuala wants to be sure to have many styles and sizes of shoes available because this is a busy time of the year with various special  events including graduations, holidays and the beginning of a new school year. 

These ladies also receive educational training once a month to enrich their knowledge about leadership, empowerment and self-esteem, women's health, nutrition and hygiene, as well as the use of medicinal plants. They also learn how to manage their loans effectively with information about budgeting, business planning, accounting, marketing and customer service. Friendship Bridge calls this effective combination of education and loans “Microcredit Plus”.

Pascuala and her friends in the “Mujeres Negociantes Nahuala” Trust Bank are anxious to secure these loans and invest in their small businesses. Most of the ladies have traditional textile businesses and so there are always supplies that they need to purchase to sustain or increase production.  In funding these loans, KIVA investors are valuable partners in the effort and are much appreciated. We look forward to providing a follow up report on the progress of these women! Thank you, KIVA investors!

loans.use: to buy inventory for her shoe store.

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
Lily is 58 years old and married. She works hard to provide for her family. She operates a general store in the Philippines, which she has been doing for five years. She earns additional income from selling food. 

Lily requested her eleventh loan from NWTF for 12,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase items such as shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell. Lily aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase items such as shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing items.

loans.name: Sibilina

texts.en:
Hello lenders! Meet Sibilina, a very hardworking, energetic young farmer. Although she has only farmed for the past two years, she is working hard and learning good farming practices. Through the profits she makes she has been able to take care of her family and provide basic needs for her parents.

Sibilina lives near Kapsowar in the Kapsumai area of Kenya, an area with good weather patterns and favorable weather conditions that support farming. Maize is a very common crop in Kenya and is a staple food for many who regularly eat “ugali,“ or hard porridge cooked from maize. One can usually buy sifted maize flour in the market, but its cost is higher because of the processing. Flour can be less expensive, however, if it is milled directly using a posho mill.

The Kapsumai area has only one diesel posho mill that serves a great number of people. The main problem here is that the posho mill keeps breaking down so farmers cannot grind their maize. Sibilina intends to change this by buying another posho mill to serve the area. She will buy an electric, rather than diesel, posho mill, as they are more reliable. Hopefully breakdowns will be few and far between.

To accomplish this, Sibilina is applying for a 65,000 KES loan through Juhudi Kilimo to buy a mill. Profits derived from the mill will be used to comfortably repay the loan. In the next two years, Sibilina sees herself established and running more than one posho mill. She patiently waits for your kindness.

loans.use: To buy an electric posho mill

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is 52 years old and married.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell like soap, spices, noodles, eggs, etc.

Zenaida has borrowed and paid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from buying and selling rice and vegetables.

She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like soap, spices, noodles, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Lealoaina

texts.en:
Lealoaina is 55 years old, widowed, and has 12 children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas, which she has been doing for five years. She sells her harvest in her community or at the market. 

Lealoaina requested a loan from SPBD, which she will use to buy a second-hand pick-up, gallons of chemicals, fertilizer, sprayers, and crops. She will use the profits from her sales to pay for her familiy's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to purchase a second-hand pick-up, gallons of chemicals, fertilizer, sprayers, and crops

loans.name: Emilsen

texts.es:
Emilsen es una mujer de 50 años de edad, casada, madre de tres hijos de 18,13, 8 años y su negocio la elaboración y venta de pan.
Ella es independiente, constante, sencilla, ordenada, y trabajadora. Su trabajo lo realiza en la zona ‘plan 4000’ de su ciudad, un lugar caracterizado por fabricas e industrias que ocupan el lugar.
Emilsen es de tez morena, estatura media, cabello largo,  su lengua materna es el español y conoce el guaraní por herencia familiar. Su vida la comparte con su esposo y sus tres hijos; los cuales estudian en la escuela y también ayudan con el trabajo. Su negocio es la elaboración y venta de pan; ella se encarga de la compra de harina y demás ingredientes para elaborar pan a diario, luego se ocupa de venderlo de forma ambulante a distintos clientes fijos como casuales. Las dificultades en su negocio comúnmente son; la escases de harina y también el mal funcionamiento de su horno, que después del uso constante se ha malogrado.
Su sueño es tener una panadería dónde poder exhibir varios tipos de panes. Ella desea expandir su negocio realizando la compra de un horno industrial y harina por mayor.
Es por esos motivos que Emilsen solicita un préstamo para la compra de un horno industrial y harina por mayor para expandir su negocio.
texts.en:
Emilsen is a 50-year-old married mother of three, ages 18, 13, and 8. Her business is making and selling bread. Emilsen is independent, reliable, simple, organized, and hard-working. She works in an area of her city called “plan 4000,” a place characterized by the factories and businesses located there. 

Emilsen is of dark complexion, medium height, and long hair. Her native language is Spanish, and she also speaks Guaraní, which she learned through her family’s heritage. Her life is shared with her husband and three children who are studying in school and also help with her business. She makes a living baking and selling bread; she is responsible for the purchase of flour and other ingredients to make the bread daily, then she travels around to sell it to her steady and one-time customers. The difficulties she experiences with her business are scarcity of flour, and the malfunction of her oven, which is in bad condition due to constant use. 

Her dream is to have a bakery where she can display various types of breads. She wants to expand her business by purchasing an industrial oven and flour in bulk. It is for these reasons that Emilsen is requesting a loan: to purchase an industrial oven, and flour in bulk, to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase an industrial oven, and flour in bulk, to expand her business.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is 47 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by raising cows in the Philippines. Marilou is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to buy an additional cow to raise for her business.

Marilou has been raising cows for 24 years and also earns additional income from raising ducks and a general store.

She successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy an additional cow to raise for her business.

loans.name: Jeanilyn

texts.en:
Jeanilyn is 51 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Jeanilyn is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Jeanilyn has been farming rice for eleven years and also earns additional income from a fishpond.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
Mylene is 34 years old and married with two children. She has worked hard running a general store for the past three years and earns an income from selling food as well.

Mylene has borrowed and repaid two loans from NWTF before this one. She is now applying for a 10,000 PHP loan to buy more items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. She is working to build and expand her business so as to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Baby

texts.en:
Baby is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a food-vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients like milk, fruits, sugar, etc for her food-vending business.

Baby has been in this business for five years. Baby earns additional income from a general store.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested this loan to further build her businesses.

Baby has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like milk, fruits, sugar, etc

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 62 years old and married, with two children.

She earns a living through a farming equipment operator business in the Philippines. Erlinda is borrowing PHP 10,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her equipment.

Erlinda has been in the farming equipment operator business for ten years and also earns additional income from motorcycle transport and farming rice.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her equipment.

loans.name: Lauriano

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Lauriano works hard to support his family.

He has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines and also earns income from farming rice. Lauriano is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to  buy spare parts and other materials for his motorcycle transport business.

Lauriano has been sustaining his business activities through his past 13 loans from NWTF. He hopes that his hard work will help him attain his dream of saving money to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and other materials for his transport business

loans.name: Maoiai

texts.en: Maoiai is 59 years old and married with eight children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for 12 years. Maoiai needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gum boots and a spade. She has been a member of SPBD since 2002. Maoiai will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gum boots and a spade

loans.name: Gina Susana

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Honduras 2000 se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo, este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas que bañan las costas de este bello lugar,  aquí la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.
En este lugar vive la señora Gina, tiene  47 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene dos hijos de 17 y de 14 años de edad, uno estudia en universidad y el menor en colegio. Su esposo se dedica a la pesca.
Doña Gina tiene un negocio de pesca y venta de pescado, ella tiene dos lanchas, las cuales son tripuladas por dos o tres personas cada una, los mismos que ganan un buen porcentaje por la pesca que logren hacer, estas personas se van a alta mar y se desplazan a la par de un barco pesquero el mismo que es tripulado por su esposo, allí ellos entregan el pescado en este barco y reciben el pago por el mismo, ellos se van por 20 a 25 días seguidos y después de este tiempo regresan  a sus hogares. Ella tiene sus lanchas 11 años y le va muy bien. 
Este crédito es para comprar redes, piolas, anzuelos, grapas, combustibles y alimentos, para los días de pesca. Lleva más de 11 años  en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos le son de gran ayuda. Sus sueños son comprar un barco más grande.
texts.en:
Honduras 2000 Communal Bank meets every two weeks in Jaramijo Canton, a beautiful place known for beautiful beaches that bathe the coast.  Most people here are very hardworking, and they work in the fishing industry.

This is where Gina lives.  She's 47 years old and married, and has two children, 17 and 14.  One attends the university and the younger one is in high school.  Her husband's a fisherman.

Gina has a fishing business; she fishes and sells fish.  She has two boats, each one with a crew of two or three people.  They earn a good percentage of the fish, going out on the high sea alongside a fishing boat that her husband crews.  They deliver the fish to that boat and receive their pay.  They go out for 20 or 25 days in a row, then return home.  She has had her boats for 11 years and it's going very well for her.

This loan is to buy nets, line, hooks, lures, fuel, and food for the fishing days.

She has been with the communal bank for more than 11 years and she likes it because the loans are a big help to her.  Her dream is to buy a bigger boat.

loans.use: to buy nets, line, hooks, lures, fuel, and food

loans.name: Jovy

texts.en:
Jovy is 43 years old and married, with five children. She works hard to provide for her family. 

She runs a general store in the Philippines and she has requested a PHP 13,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy items to sell, like shampoo and groceries.

Jovy has borrowed and paid 24 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for ten years and also earns an income from pig-fattening.

Jovy aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell, like shampoo and groceries.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is married and has three children. She works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business in the Philippines. She earns additional income from farming rice.  

Lolita requested her fourteenth loan from NWTF for 11,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase fishing net, gasoline, and other fishing materials for her fishing business. She hopes that her hard work will help save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net, gasoline, and other fishing materials

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy-and-sell vegetables business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy vegetables to sell in her food stall for her vegetables business.

Gemma has been in this business for ten years. She earns additional income from food vending.

She successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Gemma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 49 years old and married with five children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell such as shampoo, groceries, etc.

Erlinda has borrowed and repaid fourteen loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for ten years and also earns an income from a beauty salon.

Erlinda aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell such as shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Aydee Martina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal QORICHASKAS,el banco está ubicado en la provincia de Cusco.
La socia Aydeee Martina tiene 50 años de edad es separada y tiene 02 hijos, la socia alterna sus actividades diarias distribuyendo golosinas como chupetines, caramelos, galletas entre otros, la socia lleva buen tiempo dedicándose a su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de galletas entre otros.
La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
The member, Aydee Martina, belongs to the communal bank QORICHASKAS which is located in the province of Cusco. She is 50 years old, separated, and has two children. She alternates her daily activities selling snacks such as lollipops, candies, cookies, etc. She has been doing this for some time and it has been going very well for her thanks to the effort she puts into her business every day.

Aydee Martina would like to be able to continue working to support her family and is asking for the loan so she can buy cookies, etc. The member is grateful for the loan and promises to make her payments on time.

loans.use: to buy cookies, among other things.

loans.name: El Chorron Group

texts.es: Graciela, tiene 25 años de edad, tiene un hijo y vive junto a su pareja y su hijo en una aldea que pertenece al Municipio de Gracias, Lempira. Tiene cinco años de trabajar cultivando café, ya que es un negocio rentable y obtiene los ingresos necesarios para su hogar y ayuda a su esposo. La producción la vende en la misma zona donde vive. Ella solicita un préstamo por 4,000 Lempiras, que es el cuarto ciclo con la institución, este préstamo es en forma grupal y ella lo va invertir en la compra de fertilizantes, insumos y foliares para darle mantenimiento a su finca y poder mejorar la cosecha. Tiene como metas mejorar el nivel de vida con una familia digna y crecer con el cultivo. El grupo a que pertenece se llama El Chorrón, formado por tres mujeres que se dedican a la agricultura de café y residen en la misma zona. Están solicitando un préstamo grupal por 21,000 lempiras para fertilizar su finca y mejorar la producción. En la foto esta Iris a la izquierda, Rosa y Graciela a la derecha.
texts.en:
Graciela, 25, has a child.  She and her partner live with him in a village in the town of Gracias, Lempira.

She has grown coffee for five years because it's a profitable business and she earns the income she needs for her household and to help her husband.  She sells her crop in the same area where she lives.

Graciela's requesting a loan for 4,000 lempiras [HNL] in the fourth loan cycle with the bank.  This is a group loan and she's going to invest in buying fertilizer, inputs, and foliar fertilizer to take care of her farm and improve the harvest.  Her goals are to improve her standard of living with an honest family and to grow with her crop.

The group she belongs to is called El Chorrón.  It's made up of three women who live in the same area and earn a living growing coffee.  They're requesting a group loan for 21,000 lempiras to fertilize their farms and improve the crop.

In the photo, Iris is at the left and Rosa and Graciela, at the right.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, inputs, and foliar fertilizer for her coffee farm

loans.name: Shelah

texts.en:
Shelah is 25 years old and has two children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business direct-selling Avon products in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional products to sell.

Shelah has borrowed and repaid two loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the direct-selling business for one year and also earns an income from food vending.

Shelah aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional Avon products to sell

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Ofelia works hard to support her family. She earns an income fishing in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from her videoke entertainment system.

Ofelia has been developing her fishing business through her past thirteen loans from NWTF. She is now borrowing 15,000 PHP to buy new fishing equipment. She hopes that her hard work will help her save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy new fishing equipment.

loans.name: Recel

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Recel works hard to support her family.

She has a buy-and-sell vegetables and spices business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. Recel is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell for her vegetables and spices business.

Recel has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Kitenge Group

texts.en:
Zawadi, a single woman in her late 30s, has a daughter who attends school.  She has operated a beauty salon for seven years and works from 9 am to 7:30 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Zawadi's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She will use this loan to buy salon products to meet her customers' requirements.  She dreams of starting a new business to sell charcoal.

ZawadiI will share this loan with her loan business  "KITENGE" which consists of nine members who hold each other accountable to repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy salon products to meet her customers' requirements.

loans.name: Sheraton Group

texts.en:
Maariam is a married woman in her late 40s with two children who attend school. She has run a business to sell clothes for five years.  She works from 8 am to  6 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. 

This will be Mariam's 8th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase her stock of clothes and has successfully repaid the loans.  She used the profit to pay school fees, rent for her shop,  and  household expenses.  She will use this loan to buy more clothes and meet her customers' requirement and demand.  She dreams of building her own house.

Mariam will share this loan with her loan group "Sheraton" which has two members who will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

loans.use: to buy more clothes and meet her customers' requirements and demands.

loans.name: Nelida

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal QORICHASKAS, el banco está ubicado en la provincia de Cusco.
La socia Nélida  tiene 44 años de edad es conviviente  y tiene 04 hijos, la socia alterna sus actividades diarias con su negocio de venta de ropa y zapatillas, la socia lleva buen tiempo dedicándose a su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de casacas, chompas entre otros.
La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
This borrower belongs to the communal bank QORICHASKAS, located in the Cusco province.

Nélida is 44 years old, lives with her partner, and has 4 children. Her routine is a mix of daily responsibilities and her clothing/shoe business. She has worked in this business for quite some time, and it is going well, thanks to the effort that she puts into her work each day. She wants to be able to continue working, so that she can keep supporting her family.

She is requesting a loan to purchase coats, sweaters, and other items.

She is thankful for the loan and commits to making the repayments on time.

loans.use: to purchase coats, sweaters, & other items

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal QORICHASKAS, el banco está ubicado en la provincia de Cusco.
La socia Carmen tiene 54 años de edad es conviviente  y tiene 02 hijos, la socia alterna sus actividades diarias con su negocio de venta de granos secos como maíz, trigo entre otros, la socia lleva buen tiempo dedicándose a su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia es una persona responsable y empeñosa siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de maíz entre otros.
La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
This borrower belongs to the communal bank QORICHASKAS, located in the Cusco province.

Carmen is 54 years old, lives with her partner, and has 2 children. Her routine is a mix of her daily responsibilities and her business selling dried grains, such as rice, wheat, etc. She has had this business for quite some time, and it is going well, thanks to the effort she puts into her work every day. She is a responsible and hard-working person, as this is the way she supports her family.

She is requesting this loan to buy corn and other items.

She is thankful for the loan and commits to making the repayments on time.

loans.use: to purchase corn and other items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a TV to furnish her house.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is a hard-working entrepreneur who buys and-sells rice in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy additional sacks of rice to sell for her business.

Lorna has been in this business for 11 years. Lorna earns additional income from buying and selling corn.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested this loan to further build her businesses.

Lorna has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of rice grains to sell for her business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 46 years old and married with five children. For the past eight years she has worked hard running a general store and selling prepared food.

Teresita has borrowed and repaid four loans through NWTF. She is now applying for a 10,000 PHP loan to buy additional stock to sell like soap, sugar, canned goods, chips, etc. She is working to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stock for her store.

loans.name: Ma. Lourdes

texts.en:
Ma. Lourdes is 55 years old and married with six children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, milk, chips, noodles, and soft drinks.

Ma. Lourdes has borrowed and repaid 12 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for seven years and also earns an income from food vending.

Ma. Lourdes aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, milk, chips, noodles, and soft drinks

loans.name: Almira

texts.en:
Almira is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy fishing materials like a fishing net and wood for her business.

Almira has been in this business for two years. Almira earns additional income from buying and selling fish.

Almira has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like a fishing net and wood.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Corazon works hard to support her family.

She has a food-vending business in the Philippines and earns additional income from farming rice. Corazon is borrowing PHP 5,000 through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients like meat and vegetables for her food-vending business.

Corazon has been sustaining her business activities through her loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients like meat and vegetables

loans.name: Melania

texts.en:
Melania is 47 years old and married, with four children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Melania is borrowing PHP 12,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase additional sacks of feed and vitamins.

Melania has been raising pigs for six years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
As a widowed parent of two children, Erlinda works hard to support her family.

She has a buy-and-sell banana business in the Philippines and earns additional income from farming root crops. Erlinda is borrowing PHP 5,000 through NWTF to purchase additional bananas to sell for her business.

She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas to sell

loans.name: Ma. Leah

texts.en:
Ma. Leah works hard to support her family. Ma. Leah is married and has a food-vending business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food business.

Ma. Leah has been in this business for five years now.

In the future, Ma. Leah would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business

loans.name: Alfa Na Omega Group

texts.en:
Joyce is a married woman in her early 40s and has two children who attend school.  She has run a business for five years and has a vegetable garden to sell them at wholesale prices.  She works from 6:30 am to 9 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.  

This will be Joyce's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She will use this loan to buy  out of stock items, seeds, and manure.  She dreams of buying a big shamba.

Joyce will share this loan with her loan group "ALFA NA OMEGA" which consist of four members who hold each other accountable to repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy seeds and manure for her vegetable garden.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase groceries to stock her store

loans.name: Karibea Group

texts.en:
Haika is a 56-year-old married woman with three sons and three daughters.  One child attends school and the others are grown.

She has had a mamalishe (local restaurant) to  serve breakfast and lunch for ten years. She works from 6 am to 4 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

Haika has been a client for a long time and has taken several loans which she successfully repaid.  She used  previous loans to buy ingredients such as cooking oil, baking and maize flours, rice, vegetables, and meat. 

She is happy because she has seen how Kiva helps people around the world.  She managed to built a house with her profits. She believes her business will grow and be in a good position for future business. 

Haika will use her  credit to buy new chairs and a charcoal stove for her restaurant. She will share this loan with her group,Karibea, which consists of four members. The group members hold each other accountable for repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy new chairs and a charcoal stove for her restaurant.

loans.name: Ma. Wilma

texts.en:
Ma. Wilma works hard to support her family. She is married and has a buy-and-sell fruit business in the Philippines.

Ma. Wilma requested a PHP 5,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase additional baskets of fruit to sell.

Ma. Wilma has been in this business for one year now. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional baskets of fruit to sell.

loans.name: Zaida

texts.en:
Zaida works hard to support her family. She is married and has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall.

Zaida has been in this business for two years now.

In the future, Zaida would like to save enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 61 years old and has a bamboo weaving business in the Philippines. Mila has been in this business for six years.

Mila requested a PHP 18,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional bamboo to weave.

In the future, Mila would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional bamboo to weave.

loans.name: Patamban Group

texts.es:
Elías tiene 48 años, es un Purepecha nativo de la Comunidad Indígena de Patamban. Tiene 2 hijos adultos, los dos son profesionistas y universitarios. El abuelo de Elías y su papá, fueron resineros y Elías de niño trabajó también en la resina. Sin embargo, en busca de mejores oportunidades y para poder sacar a su familia adelante, siendo muy joven, Elías tuvo que abandonar su pueblo y dedicarse a la construcción en el puerto de Lázaro Cárdenas.  Al pasar de los años y ante la añoranza del cariño de sus padres, hace poco decidió regresar a Patamban su pueblo natal en la “Sierra Purépecha” con el propósito de acompañar y cuidar a sus papás, además de dedicarse a cultivar las tierras que tuvo que abandonar de joven. Por ello esta requiriendo de apoyo económico, para equipamiento y adquisición de insumos para el establecimiento de 29,040 pinos productores de resina.

 Su sueño es lograr que sus papás a pesar de tener más de los 80 años de edad, vuelvan a ver sus tierras con bosque, como cuando Elías era niño y que la vida les permita ver el fruto de las plantaciones de resina, en los huertos nuevos que va a establecer.

Elías siempre ha estado buscando una oportunidad como ésta y agradece la confianza que se le ha dado para lograr su sueño, ya que está seguro de que habrán buenos resultados, puesto que su mayor orgullo es tener la fortaleza para cumplir todos los objetivos que se propone. Por lo que piensa que solo se sentirá orgulloso hasta que logre la cosecha de estas nuevas huertas de pinos. Su mayor reto ahora es llevar las plantaciones con éxito a la cosecha. Lo que le requerirá de mucha paciencia y trabajo por más de 10 años.

Elías desea lograr una buena producción de resina y piensa que si todos se imaginaran que un árbol puede dar resina por más de ochenta años, habría más árboles en el mundo, se dejaría de cortar tanta madera y se ganaría mucho más sin dañar a la naturaleza.
texts.en: To find out more about how Ejido Verde is working to create opportunity for indigenous populations watch this video Elías is a native Purepecha from the indigenous community of Patamban. He has two adult children. Both of them have university degrees and are professionals. Elías’s grandfather and father were resin extractors. As a child, Elías also worked with resin. However, in seeking better opportunities, and in order to be able to get ahead, Elías had to abandon his village when he was very young. He worked in construction in the Lázaro Cárdenas port. As the years passed, he yearned for his parents’ affection. After a short while he decided to return to Patamban, his native village in the “Sierra Purépecha”. He did this in order to keep his parents company and to take care of them. He also did it in order to cultivate the land that he had to abandon when he was young. This is why he needs financial support for equipment and supplies to establish 29,040 pines that produce resin. His dream is to manage for his parents, in spite of being over 80 years old, to once again see their land with woods, just like when Elías was a boy. His dream is for life to allow them to see the end result of planting resin producing trees in the new groves that he will establish. Elías has always looked for an opportunity like this. He is grateful for the trust that has been given to him in order to accomplish his dream. He is sure that there will be good results. This is because his greatest pride is having the strength to meet all of his proposed goals. Therefore, he will only feel proud when he obtains the harvest from these new pine groves. His biggest challenge now is successfully harvesting the resin. This will require much patience from him and work for more than ten years. Elías wishes to get a good resin production. He thinks that if everyone realized that a tree is able to produce resin for over 80 years, there would be more trees in the world. They would stop cutting down so much wood, and they would earn a lot more without damaging nature.

loans.use: To buy and plant resin producing pine trees – the resin will be harvested annually, providing income for many years.

loans.name: Keri Group

texts.es:
Verónica tiene 39 años de edad y es líder de un grupo de indígenas formado por cuatro mujeres y nueve hombres en la Comunidad  de Cherán Atzicurín, en el Estado de Michoacán, México, de donde es nativa. Verónica pertenece a la etnia de los Purepechas y está casada con Martin, ambos se dedican al trabajo de campo de donde obtienen sus pocos ingresos económicos. Tienen seis hijos;  Maricela la mayor de edad tiene 24 años, Juan Carlos 22, Angélica 18, Verónica 16,  Daici  12, y la más pequeña María José tiene 3 años, todos asisten a la escuela.

Junto con el grupo, poseen un terreno forestal en donde planean establecer su primer huerta de pinos resineros. El préstamo lo requieren para la adquisición y plantación de 28,050 pinos resineros,  el cercado de los predios, la eliminación de maleza y la limpieza del terreno así como para la adquisición de fertilizante.

El sueño de Verónica es tener en el futuro una cosecha de resina que le de ingresos suficientes para el sustento y estudio para sus hijos. Lo que la hace sentir orgullosa es poder plantar pinos con su familia y vecinos, a la vez que contribuyen a la conservación de su bosque al rescate de una actividad productiva que hace algunos años daba sustento a por lo menos 100 familias de su comunidad. 

A Verónica le gustaría agradecerle mucho a todos los que están apoyando a comunidades indígenas que viven en regiones pobres,  para que, con un poco de ayuda pueden cristalizar un negocio del cual vivir y que sus hijos puedan seguir el oficio del resinero. Opina, que el negocio de la resina le servirá al medio ambiente y que los retos y desafíos se verán en su momento, ya que es la primera vez que realizará un proyecto de este tipo. Sin embargo, cuenta con la confianza y entusiasmo para salir adelante y lograr un buena cosecha de resina de pino.
texts.en: To find out more about how Ejido Verde is working to create opportunity for indigenous populations watch this video Verónica, age 39, is the leader of a group of indigenous people. The group is comprised of four women and nine men in the Cherán Atzicurín community in the state of Michoacán, México. She is a native of this area. Verónica is of the Purepecha ethnicity. She is married to Martin. Both of them work in the field, where they get their small incomes. They have six children. Maricela, the oldest, is 24; Juan Carlos is 22; Angélica is 28, Verónica is 16; Daici is 12; and the smallest, María José, is 3. They all go to school. Together with the group, they have a piece of forest land where they plan to establish their first grove of resin producing pine trees. They need the loan to get and plant 28,050 resin producing pines, to fence the property, to weed and clear the land, and to get fertilizer. Verónica’s dream is to have a resin harvest in the future that gives her enough income to support her family and for her children’s education. At the same time, they are contributing to the conservation of the forest by reclaiming a productive activity that a few years ago supported a least 100 families in her community. Verónica would like to greatly thank everyone who is supporting indigenous communities who are living in poor regions. With a little help, they will be able to crystallize a business upon which they can live, and their children will be able to continue with the trade of extracting resin. She feels that the resin business will help the atmosphere, and that the goals and challenges will be worked out in due course. This is the first time that she will engage in a project of this type. Nevertheless, she has the confidence and the enthusiasm to get ahead and achieve a good harvest of pine resin.

loans.use: To buy and plant resin producing pine trees – the resin will be harvested annually, providing income for many years.

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza is 43 years old and married with four children, all of whom are in school. Liza works very hard to provide for them.

Liza runs a buy-and-sell business (Tupperware products) in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock of items to sell such as Tupperware, etc.

Liza has been in this business for three years.

In the future, Liza would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of items to sell such as Tupperware, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to maintain and repair his taxi.

loans.name: Dave

texts.en:
Dave sells second-hand clothing and she requests a loan to buy clothing and other used items to resell.

Dave is a married woman with three children and they live in a little town in northern Albania.  Her younger son passed away in a tragic accident, he was 25 years old. 

She states: “All I have been doing for  20 years has been selling used items, especially clothes. The very first years, me and others in the same type of business, made good money. Now it’s not that busy, but it is something. I stopped it for sometime because I was grieving  and I could not go out of home, let alone run any a business. But later on, talking to my customers became therapy that helped me out of depression and grief."

loans.use: to buy second hand clothing to resell.

loans.name: Yeimy

texts.es: Yeimy de 31 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza, en un punto comercial ubicado en el municipio donde habita.  Tintes, champú, tratamientos capilares y cosméticos, son los artículos de su oferta que más vende, entre sus amistades, vecinos y referidos por estos. Yeimy compra los productos  de contado a proveedores especializados, con el fin de encontrar precios que puedan satisfacer las necesidades y posibilidades de compra de sus clientes.  Su meta más adelante es tener un almacén, para vender al mayoreo, es decir ser la distribuidora de estos artículos, en pequeños negocios y personas naturales. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento  que hace a la Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará acondicionadores de cabello, tinturas y en general productos capilares. Con ello tendría más variedad de productos y así continuaría los pasos de éxito de su madre, de quien aprendió la actividad comercial, cuando como extensión del negocio de ella empezó a ofrecer artículos que ella le proveía, hasta lograr generar ingreso independientes. Con esta inversión su negocio mejorará porque aprovechará la temporada decembrina para impactar con nuevas a ofertas a sus clientes y vender aún más, haciendo de su credikiva una inversión exitosa..
texts.en:
Yeimy is 31 years old and sells beauty products from a sales outlet located in the municipality where she lives. Hair dyes, shampoo, hair treatments and cosmetics are the products from her selection that she sells the most of to friends, neighbors and people referred by them. Yeimy buys the product for cash from specialized suppliers, with the aim of finding prices that will satisfy the needs and means of her customers.

Her goal is to someday have a wholesale store–that is, to be a distributor of these items, both to small businesses and individuals. 

Currently she is applying for a credikiva loan, her first from Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo, by means of which she will buy hair conditioners, dyes, and hair products in general. This way she would have a greater variety of products and would continue her mother's path to success. She learned the business from her mother, when as an extension of her mother's business, she began to sell items that she provided her, until she generated an independent income. 

With this investment her business will improve because she will take advantage of the December season to impress her customers with new stock and sell even more, making her credikiva a successful investment.

loans.use: To buy hair conditioners, dyes, and hair products in general.

loans.name: Dava

texts.en:
The winter has begun in the regioun where Dava lives yet she is not ready to welcome the harsh weather. The roof of the family's home is almost on the ground and they wait for financial help to have it repaired. 

Dave also wants to purchase some goats to raise for the milk. Dave sends her gratitude to all of her lenders who made it possible for her to previously build the stable.

loans.use: to buy goats & repair the  roof of her house.

loans.name: St. Francis School

texts.en:
Greetings from Uganda! This is Edward. He is the Head Teacher of St. Francis Junior School a mixed school in the Peri-urban area of Budo, Wakiso District with 700 students.
